tips.title: Gluten-Free Binding Agents
tips.content: When converting recipes, you may need to add binding agents like xanthan gum, guar gum, or psyllium husk to replace the binding properties of gluten.

tips.title: Creating Gluten-Free Flour Blends
tips.content: A good all-purpose gluten-free flour blend typically contains rice flour, potato starch, and tapioca starch. Add xanthan gum for better texture.

tips.title: Mixing Techniques
tips.content: Gluten-free batters often need more mixing than traditional recipes. Mix until smooth and well-combined, but don't overmix as it can make baked goods tough.

tips.title: Resting Time
tips.content: Let gluten-free batters rest for 10-15 minutes before baking. This allows the flours to hydrate properly and improves texture.

tips.title: Oven Temperature Adjustments
tips.content: Gluten-free baked goods often benefit from slightly lower oven temperatures (25-50Â°F lower) and longer baking times to prevent over-browning.

tips.title: Storage Tips
tips.content: Gluten-free baked goods tend to dry out faster. Store in airtight containers and consider adding a slice of bread to maintain moisture.

tips.title: Preventing Cross-Contamination
tips.content: Always use separate utensils, cutting boards, and storage containers for gluten-free ingredients. Clean surfaces thoroughly before preparing gluten-free foods.

tips.title: Reading Labels
tips.content: Always check labels for hidden gluten sources like malt, modified food starch, and natural flavors. Look for 'gluten-free' certification when possible.
